channel.title: Solitudes on My New Hugo Site
channel.description: Recent content in Solitudes on My New Hugo Site

item.description:
Talk Notes: The Two Solitudes for Hackers

by Tavish Armstrong / tavisharmstrong at gmail dot com / @tavarm

These are notes on a talk I gave at PyCon 2014. I hope this is a useful reference for anyone who saw the talk and wants to learn more about what I spoke about.

If you are interested in what I spoke about in this talk, please, please, get in touch via email. A lot of people mentioned afterwards that they'd be interested in a mailing list or something similar. My hope is that we can gain momentum by working on this together and motivating each other.

Video

The slides are not exactly useful as a reference, but some people like them as a way to jog their memory. They are available here if you are one of those people!

Papers, Books, Notebooks, Talks, etc.

  • Greg Wilson: What We Actually Know About Software Development, and Why We Believe It's True from CUSEC 2010
  • It Will Never Work In Theory - a blog about software engineering research.
    • Post: Best Practises for Mining Software Repositories
    • Post: Happy software developers solve problems better
    • Post: An Empirical Investigation into Programming Language Syntax
  • Me: How Long Does It Take To Review an IPython Pull Request? (repository)
  • Rigby and Bird, 2013: Convergent Contemporary Software Peer Review Practices
  • Hindle, 2009: Mining Recurrent Activities: Fourier Analysis of Change Events
  • The Leprechauns of Software Engineering
  • Visualize your Git Workflow by Julia Evans
